newsitem.title: CHINA: China to establish T-bond market-maker system.
newsitem.headline: China to establish T-bond market-maker system.

text.p: China's Finance Ministry is considering establishing a treasury bond market-maker system to promote public trading in state debt, the Shanghai Securities News said on Wednesday.

Under the system, the ministry would require major banks and securities houses to maintain a certain volume of trading and work to keep stable prices on the T-bond secondary or public trading market, the newspaper said.
The ministry is also making efforts to set up a national T-bond clearing system to cope with increasing demand for T-bond trading on the secondary market, it said.

"Establishing a national clearing system and a market-maker system is aimed at supplying better services for individuals to trade on the secondary market," the newspaper quoted unnamed sources at the ministry as saying.

The newspaper said the ministry was considering the new moves after the successful implementation of a number of reforms to the T-bond primary or issue market this year, prompting the need for the further development of the secondary market.

The most outstanding feature of the reforms was the use of public tender system for most issues, which brought coupons of state debt closer to market needs and ensured a smooth issue, the newspaper quoted the sources as saying.
The ministry is also looking into setting up special T-bond investment funds to enable individuals to invest on the secondary market through the funds, the newspaper said.

It will gradually introduce a unified way of calculating T-bond prices and yields to lead the the secondary market settlement system in comformity with international practice, the newspaper said, but giving no details.
China issued a total of 220 billion yuan T-bonds this year, the third successive year of record state debt issues.
Treasury bills and bonds have been best sellers this year due to falling inflation and lower bank interest rates.
"The Finance Ministry as the issuer and manager of state debt is optimistic about the prospects of the development of the T-bond secondary market," the newspaper quoted the sources as saying.
